record.pwc_title: Tech tip: Time to Chat
record.pwc_description: How is Google Chat different from “classic” Hangouts?
record.pwc_body: Tech tip: Time to Chat Tech tip: Time to Chat PwC Technology Sept. 18, 2018 There’s been a lot of excitement about Google’s new instant messaging platform. Thousands of you have already downloaded the new Hangouts Chat mobile app. We’ve seen praise for features like Chat rooms, Meet integration and the ability to send images (which may have something to do with GIFs, but we like fun, too). You also had some great questions we’ll address here. How is Google Chat different from “classic” Hangouts? Here’s a sampling of the major differences. Chat lets you: Send screenshots, transfer files and share documents Create “Rooms” for your project or team, where you can save data and conversation history for six months (you’ve already created nearly 1500 Rooms!) Send “Direct messages” that disappear after 24 hours, just like Hangouts Start a Meet videoconference with one click Chat with PwC colleagues in all global territories currently using Google How do I access Chat? Is there an app? Download the Hangouts Chat mobile app from PwC’s App Store. We may release a desktop app for PC at a later date, but for now we use Chat right in Chrome: visit chat.google.com (right-click the browser tab to pin it). Remember, this is a newer tool and -- like us -- Google is focused on continuous improvement. What will happen to the old Hangouts? Google will keep Hangouts available for some time as Chat continues to evolve, but Google plans to retire Hangouts. One-to-one messages shared in Chat will be visible in Hangouts and vice versa. However, Rooms, screenshots, files, documents, Group messages and invitations to Chat groups will only be shareable in Chat. Why am I getting multiple notifications? If you have both Chat and Hangouts open, you may see two notifications for each message -- it’s best to choose just one tool. You can manage your notifications to allow or block each app, and also adjust notifications in the tools themselves. In Chat, click the gear icon and select Notification settings. In Hangouts, click the three dots → Options → Notifications. (Google recently changed how Chrome manages notifications -- with pop-ups in your PC’s Action Center in the lower-right corner -- but this is not caused by Chat.) What about Salesforce Chatter? Can we get Slack instead? Google Chat doesn’t replace Chatter. You should continue to use your current Salesforce Chatter groups to connect with your Account teams and for all Salesforce-related information. And no, we won’t be getting Slack anytime soon due to document retention and other security concerns. Can we talk about client work? You can use Chat just like you used Hangouts -- for both direct and group messages. However, that means that you should not use Chat or Hangouts for discussions covering information subject to an OGC legal hold. Don't post data about US clients or engagements in Google Chat Rooms, where it will be retained for six months. As always, follow the US Google Business Rules. How can I learn more? Watch the recorded Chat Connect ‘n’ Learn session here. View this short video or read this document Visit the G Suite Learning Center Do you have feedback on PwC's technology and support options? Join us for a 45-minute interactive focus group to help to bring the firm's tech strategy to life. Click here to register. #PwCUSIT Top News

record.pwc_title: USAA steps it up with PwC's Source to Pay Integrated Solution.
record.pwc_body: USAA steps it up with PwC's Source to Pay Integrated Solution. USAA steps it up with PwC's Source to Pay Integrated Solution. Advisory - test May 2, 2019 Client problem: The United Services Automobile Association (USAA) is a Fortune 500 diversified financial services company offering banking, investing, and insurance to people and families who serve, or served, in the United States military. Due to an increase in assets, USAA jumped from a mid-tier to a large-tier bank, which meant more stringent regulatory requirements. The client requested an independent assessment of its overall Procurement and Third Party Risk Management (TPRM) capabilities. We delivered an elevator pitch (literally), which led to displacing our competitors who were midway through a TPRM project with the client(ouch)! We created a Magic Moment... We quickly demonstrated our value through an xLOS unified approach to an integrated Procurement and TPRM operating model. We staged a mock elevator ride for each of the team leads to share their workstream pitches. They were asked random questions by their team — which had been previously taped under their chair — leading to laughter and relaxed body language which changed the mood in the room instantaneously. This approach allowed personal perspectives to shine and brought meaningful conversations and an overall positive outcome. The USAA Program PMO ended the meeting with a smile saying, “We never have meetings like this at USAA.” We have increased the firm revenue from $700k to $35 million in less than 18 months. The solution and value we brought Leveraging the Source to Pay Integrated Solution, we incorporated the vision, policy, and value management framework and roles. Through additional value capture analysis, we have also projected year-over-year savings of at least 1% - 3% on $3.3B of addressable spend. Investing the time and energy upfront to deeply understand the client’s true needs allowed us to develop our winning approach, which incorporated elements of the Risk & Regulatory and Fit for Growth platforms. We automated various processes to remove redundancies, and we reduced complexity by standardizing practices, policies, and procedures. Meet the USAA Team! Thanks also to the following leadership team members: Becky Mackin, Martin Thomas, Rob Walley, Brett Anton, Charles Bruen, Michael Clark, Mirna Elia, Steven Klatt-Lasso, Jared Larkin, Leah Odom, Katee Puterbaugh, Akil Rao, Dan Schultz, Dominic Sugrue, Eric Willyoung What is Source to Pay? Source to Pay is more than a process, it’s a holistic approach, encompassing both Source to Contract and Procure to Pay. Source to Contract (S2C) applies to most of the upfront strategic initiatives, selecting and contracting with suppliers. Procure to Pay (P2P) is the transactional buying process of the good or service. The S2P process spans multiple stakeholder groups like Procurement, Finance, Tax & Treasury, Risk & Controls, and Business Units and is enabled by key functionality to create and efficient user experience. Contact the Source to Pay Integrated Solution team - we’re here to help! We know there are many more stories to tell. Please let us know if you have an Integrated Solutions win we should feature. Want to learn more about Integrated Solutions? Check out Consulting Source and the Integrated Solutions Learning Hub. Top News

record.pwc_title: A Windows 10 upgrade is coming — Plan ahead for minimal disruption
record.pwc_description: The OS update is on hold while we make some system adjustments. We'll update this article when we're ready to proceed -- thanks for your patience..
record.pwc_body: A Windows 10 upgrade is coming — Plan ahead for minimal disruption A Windows 10 upgrade is coming — Plan ahead for minimal disruption PwC Technology May 14, 2019 The OS update is on hold while we make some system adjustments. We'll update this article when we're ready to proceed -- thanks for your patience. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- It’s almost time for your PC to get the latest version of Windows 10! These annual system updates are required for your online safety and our firm’s compliance responsibilities. You won’t be able to use your PC for up to an hour, and the process can take two hours in total. When is this happening? The upgrade will roll out by LoS over the coming weeks, starting this week with IFS. Upgrades must be completed by Dec 30. After that time, Microsoft will no longer support the older version of Windows 10, and you won’t be able to connect to PwC’s network. But don’t worry — we’ve allowed plenty of time so you can plan when to upgrade. What to expect during your Windows 10 upgrade This update consists of two stages, and each can take up to an hour. You can use your PC during the initial stage, but you won’t be able to during the latter. Here’s what will happen: You’ll receive a pop-up message labeled Restart Utility. If it’s not a convenient time, you may defer for a week (more on this below). To continue with the upgrade, select Install; the update will begin in the background. You can continue to use your PC. 2. When it’s time to proceed, you’ll see a restart notification. Note that after you select Restart Now, you won’t be able to use your PC for up to an hour. Save all your data and restart promptly (the PC will restart on its own after two hours). 3. During installation, you’ll see the screen below. The update can’t be paused or deferred at this point; any interruption could cause a critical error. Your PC will automatically reboot several times. No action is needed, so take a break! You’ll know the upgrade is complete when you see your Windows logon screen. Now your PC is up to date, and it’s business as usual. Did you defer? Restart the upgrade in Software Center If you defer the initial pop-up, you don’t have to wait until you get the next one. Software Center is the new home to install all firm-provided software (it replaces Software Installer; for details refer to this guide). To restart the Windows 10 upgrade: Click the Windows Search icon, type Software Center and select it from the menu. On the “Updates” tab, select “Feature update to Windows 10…” and click Install. You can continue to use your PC while the installation begins (this can take up to an hour); the process will continue as described in step two above. Questions? Visit PwC’s Service Hub for technology help and resources. Top News

record.pwc_title: Marathoners in our midst
record.pwc_body: Marathoners in our midst Marathoners in our midst People Team May 30, 2019 PwCers across the firm are bringing our Your Tomorrow strategy to life by prioritizing well-being through Be well, work well to help them recharge. Experienced Associate Chris Manuszak and Manager Patrick McFall run marathons to boost their energy and find balance, even during the busiest periods. With the support of their colleagues, they’re crossing finish lines in impressive style. Patrick competes in some of the world’s toughest endurance races. Earlier this month, he finished a 155-mile (250 km) race through the African Namib desert. This was his third ultra-marathon, having previously run through the Atacama Desert and the mountains of Patagonia in Argentina. According to Patrick, “PwC’s culture of flexibility and well-being made it possible to train for and travel to these international marathons. Despite our hectic work schedule, my peers and leadership team encouraged me to pursue my personal goals. I’m grateful to work for a firm that values its people and prioritizes well-being.” Chris completed the Boston marathon in April and fulfilled his goal of racing three marathons over the past year. “It wasn’t easy training through the cold winter in Michigan, especially while consistently working 50+ hour weeks and fulfilling various client obligations,” he says. “Through it all, my team supported my goals, even though my morning runs meant I would come in later some days. With their help, the hard work paid off and I finished the race in Boston with a time of 2:58.” Patrick and Chris recognize the importance of well-being and understand how PwC’s commitment to flexibility can help them meet their personal goals. By communicating with their teams and setting reasonable expectations, they achieved their marathon ambitions while also fulfilling their client-service obligations. Do you have personal goals you want to achieve and need some time away? Put your plans on the agenda for your next team meeting. Talk with your team about how you can protect the time so you can disconnect and recharge and then help your teammates do the same. Share your well-being story here. Resources to help you continue your well-being journey: Be well, work well toolkit: Our interactive toolkit makes it easy for teams to integrate well-being into their meetings and programs. Our new Ginger Emotional Support app provides confidential emotional health support for each of us and our family members (age 18+) at no cost. Journeys digital coaching, available through Well-Being Rewards, offers modules to help you deal with stress and promote emotional well-being. Access the Habit Bank to try out new habits in all four dimensions of energy. Top News

record.pwc_title: Emotional health coaches are on call 24/7 with the free Ginger Emotional Support app
record.pwc_body: Emotional health coaches are on call 24/7 with the free Ginger Emotion Emotional health coaches are on call 24/7 with the free Ginger Emotional Support app National Benefits May 15, 2019 We all have things we are dealing with each day — maybe we’re stressed about an important client meeting, trying to resolve an argument with a family member or just need some support getting through a hard day. Be well, work well is a central part of our Your Tomorrow strategy — and that includes not only physical well-being, but also taking care of our emotional and mental well-being. As you heard on the Firmwide Town Hall, our new Ginger Emotional Support app provides confidential emotional health support for each of us and our family members (age 18+)1 at no cost. Live coaches can chat with you on demand via the app anytime, anywhere. It's free, convenient and completely confidential — any information you share is kept private between you and your coaches. You do not need to be enrolled in a PwC medical plan in order to take advantage of this service. What can you connect with an emotional health coach about? Coaches ask questions to get a clear understanding of your lifestyle and goals to create a personalized plan. Ginger coaches can help with: Achieving goals Recovering from loss Building self-esteem Improving communication Getting through a hard day To get started: Visit PwC's Ginger registration site at http://bit.ly/gingerpwc. On that page, register to access Ginger by entering your PwC Google email address2. You’ll receive a welcome email from Ginger with three access codes - one for you, and two for your spouse/domestic partner/dependents (age 18+) should they choose to use the service. If you need additional codes for other dependents, contact the Ginger team at help@ginger.io. Download the Ginger Emotional Support app from the PwC App Store (available for Android and iOS). Once in the app, enter the unique code that was sent to your PwC email address. From there, you'll be able to select any email address you choose. How is emotional health coaching different from therapy? Coaching is solely focused on providing day-to-day support and guidance, and helping develop the skills you need to overcome a barrier or achieve a goal. The goals of therapy are broader. Therapy is designed specifically for people who need to deepen their self-awareness or better understand their thoughts and feelings. After working with you, a coach may recommend therapy, depending on your goals. If you already work with a therapist, you can still rely on a coach for additional day-to-day support. To be our best, we need to take care of ourselves. Even if you feel like you don’t need this resource right now, it’s good to know that help is there whenever and wherever you need it. If you want to learn more about Ginger, check out the FAQs or email the Ginger team at help@ginger.io. And, keep an eye out for colleagues walking around the office wearing green ribbons in support of reducing the stigma around mental health in honor of Mental Health Month. 1 Partners and staff, and their spouse/domestic partner and dependents age 18+. 2 If you are a new hire, it may take 10-14 days before you can register with Ginger due to file transmission timing. record.pwc_body: Have you spoken to your client today? Document substantive verbal advi Have you spoken to your client today? Document substantive verbal advice and emails in DMS. One Firm Risk Organization April 18, 2019 It’s critical to keep in mind the importance of documenting our work, including significant discussions -- internally and with the client -- throughout the engagement. All substantive client discussions related to the engagement -- including phone calls -- should be documented and included in the engagement file in DMS. Engagement teams should use professional judgment in deciding which client discussions and/or phone calls are “of substance” to the engagement, as well as in the overall preparation of the documentation. It’s recommended that engagement teams review the Documentation Toolkit for guidance on appropriate documentation. Useful tools and templates are available in the Toolkit to assist with the documentation process, such as a template that can be used to document verbal advice provided during client discussions and phone calls. The “File to TaxDMS” button - a Chrome extension available for download from the PwC Chrome Store - makes it easier to file Google emails and email attachments to DMS with a few simple clicks. Access this File to DMS from Gmail - Quick Reference Guide for instructions on how to add and use the “File to TaxDMS” button. As a reminder, the quality and contemporaneous filing of appropriate documentation for engagements is formally being assessed as part of the Tax Office Review program, including the documentation of substantive client discussions related to the engagement. For additional information related to the Tax Office Review Documentation Evaluation, please access this link for a template of the assessment and relevant help guidance. record.pwc_title: Let’s get (more) digital with Salesforce
record.pwc_body: Let’s get (more) digital with Salesforce Let’s get (more) digital with Salesforce HQ News July 31, 2018 The latest release makes Salesforce an even better digital experience for you. Just like updates to apps on an iPhone, we continuously make improvements to Salesforce functionality and capability, based on your feedback and the latest technology. Here’s what’s new and improved in the Aug. 6 release: Unlocking won opportunities is more convenient The Opportunity Owner and Opportunity Lead can now unlock a won opportunity to make edits if needed. After clicking the “Unlock Opportunity” button, details on the opportunity are editable for the next seven days. At that point, the opportunity will close automatically unless the Owner or Lead adjusts the stage from “won” to a previous stage. Connect closed opportunities without reopening Click on the "Connect Existing Opportunity" button to connect existing closed opportunities without having to re-open them. Also use the button to connect multiple opportunities. Searching for users to add to an opportunity team just got easier When adding team members to an opportunity team, searching for a person’s name will show you the name, territory, LoS and email address. These additional fields will help to distinguish between people who have the same name. New “Role” field in Contacts adds helpful details A new field for “Role” on the Contact page standardizes how contacts can be grouped by their functional area within an organization. This field, located above “Buying Role,” includes finance, human resources, IT, internal audit, legal, marketing, operations, risk & compliance, sales, strategy, tax, executive, audit committee and board member. Post-meeting notes are easier to find You can now find notes created from an Introhive post-meeting capture digest on the client record in the activities tab under the “Past Activities” heading as a “Closed Task.” Release outage While enhancements are made, Salesforce will be unavailable from Friday, Aug. 3 at 9 p.m. ET to Sunday, Aug. 5 at 11 a.m. ET. Questions? Need help? The US/MX Salesforce Spark site is your one-stop shop for all things Salesforce. Plus, the Salesforce Total Care Network is always available -- you can even schedule a 30-minute appointment with the Business Support Team. Top News

record.pwc_body: Get Smart about Pricing Get Smart about Pricing HQ News May 24, 2019 One Firm Smart Pricing is here! It’s our strategy to be paid for the value we deliver and the Your Tomorrow investments we’re making to tech-enable our services and processes. What’s coming next: In the coming months, we’ll introduce business guidelines and preferred pricing structures for many of our services and products, a Smart Pricing tool for select businesses and products and upskilling opportunities related to pricing and value acumen. Here’s what you can do now: Everyone has the opportunity to get to know our pricing strategy and where we are heading. For those that have access to the microsite, here are some ways to get started: Make a move on the Pricing Gameboard for the key Pricing Structures and Enablers. record.pwc_title: Sweet streams are made of these
record.pwc_description: Google Meet's standard limit recently rose to 100 participants — and while that allows a lot of collaboration, some may need to include a larger group. Now reach more PwCers with Google Meet's new Live Stream feature.
record.pwc_body: Sweet streams are made of these Sweet streams are made of these PwC Technology April 15, 2019 Google Meet's standard limit recently rose to 100 participants — and while that allows a lot of collaboration, some may need to include a larger group. Now reach more PwCers with Google Meet's new Live Stream feature. Live Stream is ideal for when you anticipate a lot of PwC viewers and don’t need to interact directly with them (e.g., you don’t need to chat with them or track their attendance). This tool is also a great option to manage which attendees are able to contribute to the Meet versus view only. Keep in mind that just like link sharing, any PwC Live Stream viewer or participant can further share the link with others in the PwC network. Since attendance isn’t tracked, the owner/organizer will not know how many other individuals view the content. Don’t use Live Stream to discuss confidential or sensitive info. Live streams are only viewable to those with PwC Google accounts — external clients or colleagues are not able to view. Again, live stream links can be shared anywhere within the PwC network and the Meet owner won’t have the ability to determine who streamed the Meet. As with all things Google, be sure to follow the Global Google Business Rules and US Business Rules when using these tools. How to schedule a Live Stream Create a Google Calendar invite. Click Add conferencing and select Hangouts Meet. Then, click the Hangout Meets drop down menu and select Add Live Stream. Your Calendar invite will then have two links — one for the Meet and another for the Live Stream. Those who join the regular Meet link can broadcast on the Live Stream, so only include presenters in that invite. It’s best to create a separate calendar invite for the Live Stream attendees. Live Stream is available to any individual who has a PwC Google account. How to start your Live Stream When you start your Meet session, you’ll see a prompt to start streaming (or click the three dots at the bottom and select Start streaming). A red “Live” alert will appear in the top left to let you and your participants know you’re live streaming. For more info, refer to these FAQs. Top News

record.pwc_title: Be a star in someone else’s story
record.pwc_body: Be a star in someone else’s story Be a star in someone else’s story Responsible Business Leadership June 14, 2018 Two-thirds of students in the US will grow up without an adult mentor, advisor or trusted ally to help guide them toward education and career success. These relationships are absolutely critical, which is why mentoring is a cornerstone of our Access Your PotentialⓇ commitment. Many of us were fortunate to have someone in our lives who played this role, helping us with everything from applying for financial aid to choosing a college major. Too many students across the country may not be so lucky, especially those seeking to become the first in their families to go to college. In fact, only 27% of first-generation students earn a degree after four years, compared to 42% of students who come from families with higher-education experience. Hundreds of PwCers are stepping up to close this gap by paying it forward -- sharing the guidance they themselves received, along with their own personal experiences, as part of ongoing mentoring relationships with young people across the country. Here are three of their stories: Jordan Jobs, New York Metro, iMentor Joining iMentor has been a great experience. iMentor pairs young professionals with public high school students in low-income communities to provide mentorship through their high school years, and ultimately help them through the college application process. As a young black woman with few visible role models growing up, I was inspired to join iMentor to guide another young woman to achieve her dreams of attending college. I have had the pleasure of getting to know my mentee, Mia, and I look forward to watching her grow. Veon Watson, Hallandale, Sunland Park Elementary School Each Career Day I present to students on career choices in digital. I provide an overview of my job as a Digital Analyst + Digital Strategist. I also highlight my experience as a Woman in STEM (especially being a minority woman) and provide encouragement to the female students on pursuing a career in STEM regardless of biases that may exist. Sunland Park is an inner-city, lower-income school that does not provide a lot of exposure for career options in this realm. Cassandra Thompson, Cleveland, College Now Greater Cleveland College Now Greater Cleveland guides students of all ages across Northeastern Ohio, helping them achieve their dreams of higher education and career success. As a mentor, I email my mentee twice a month and meet in person twice a year for the duration of their college journey. I was matched to my first mentee (pictured) this school year, so our journey began in August. In New York, Chicago or the Bay Area? Check out our upcoming information sessions to learn more about becoming an iMentor. New York: June 26 - sign up via Impact Space July 24 - sign up via Impact Space Aug. 21 - sign up via Impact Space Chicago: July 17 - sign up via Impact Space Bay Area: Upcoming iMentor-hosted info sessions Elsewhere? Reach out to your Access Your Potential Office Champion to learn about local nonprofit organizations that offer mentoring. On the go? CareerVillage offers the opportunity to connect with high school and college virtually and share your advice on everything from student loans to careers in professional services. Top News

record.pwc_title: Get the job done with TalentLink’s Bulletin Board feature
record.pwc_body: Get the job done with TalentLink’s Bulletin Board feature Get the job done with TalentLink’s Bulletin Board feature People Team Feb. 14, 2019 Part of our digital journey entails experimenting with new technologies and taking on projects that require specialized skills. From analyzing large data sets, to presenting data with nifty dashboards and building bots, we’re digitally upskilling in countless ways. If you’re working on a project and need specific skills or extra resources, TalentLink’s Bulletin Board feature can help. What is the TalentLink Bulletin Board? The Bulletin Board is a TalentLink feature that allows you to post small and short-term assignments and projects. It efficiently connects those who need an extra pair of hands with those who are looking for new opportunities and ways to demonstrate their skills. Who can use the Bulletin Board? All partners and staff can post to the Bulletin Board to request help on internal or client work that requires 20 hours or less (e.g., client engagements, recruiting events, proposal support, internal initiatives). Everyone can also search the Bulletin Board for available opportunities and “raise their hands” to be considered for assignments. Note: Having a detailed and regularly updated TalentLink profile can help increase your chances of being selected for projects. How does it work? It’s simple! Launch TalentLink Bulletin Board or click on the “Thumbtack” icon in the left navigation from TalentLink homepage. A new window will open with all the available opportunities. Need help on a project? Just click on “Create a new role” at the top left to post it to the Bulletin Board. See a project where you can help? Click on “Consider me for this role.” See a cool role for a colleague? You can share it with anyone in the US firm by clicking the Share button under the role, then clicking + to search for the person’s last name. Click here to learn more about Bulletin Board and how it works. Top News

record.pwc_title: Staying safe during busy times
record.pwc_body: Staying safe during busy times Staying safe during busy times US Security Jan. 8, 2019 Your personal safety is our highest priority. As we enter into a particularly busy season with fewer daylight hours, we want to remind you of precautions you can take to ensure your safety in, and traveling to and from, the office. Walk in pairs to your vehicle or public transportation. Or, if your building offers the service, have building security escort you to your vehicle. If your building has attached parking and you need to stay late, you can submit an expense to be reimbursed for parking fees if you move your car into building parking after 5 p.m. Support office security by displaying your badge -- and help make sure others do the same. If anyone attempts to follow you in without a badge, politely direct them to reception or building security. The best defense includes being alert, aware and prepared. Wherever you are, be aware of your surroundings, avoid isolated areas and be protective of your laptop and personal belongings. Get to know the security programs in place to protect and support you, your family and the firm during crisis and emergency situations. To-do, today -- some security basics: You know to dial 911 first in an emergency. But did you also know that the PwC Emergency Hotline is a critical secondary line of support and guidance for you and your family? Program the number into your mobile device today -- it’s also printed on your PwC security badge for quick reference. 1-888-755-1515 (US) 00-1-813-351-6460 (outside US, collect calls accepted) Make sure your personal information is up-to-date in Workday. Register at least one emergency contact with PwC so our crisis teams can support you when you need it. Visit our US Security site for additional resources and helpful videos on more actions you can take to protect yourself, your colleagues and the firm. Remember, you are PwC’s most important asset. We want you to be safe and secure, no matter where you are. Top News

record.pwc_title: How your missing trash can is good for the environment
record.pwc_body: How your missing trash can is good for the environment How your missing trash can is good for the environment Responsible Business Leadership May 6, 2019 As you heard during our recent Firmwide Town Hall, one of the ways we deliver on our purpose is through our commitment to make an impact in our communities and deliver business value by helping create a more equitable society. You can support the firm’s Responsible Business Leadership strategy in many ways -- through Access Your Potential and other volunteer opportunities, giving, Green Teams and more. Running our business responsibly means taking care to be environmentally responsible, and we’ve accomplished a lot in this area: We’ve reduced our net carbon footprint by 45% over the past 10 years. We purchase renewable energy certificates (RECs) to cover 100% of the carbon emissions from our firmwide electricity use. Starting in FY19, we offset 100% of our carbon emissions from air travel through the purchase of tree reforestation efforts and other offset programs. We reduced energy consumption per employee by 40% through more efficient use of office space and encouraging people to work remotely. 63% of our office space is LEED interior certified, meeting the highest industry design standards for environmental efficiency. We reuse or recycle all of the firm's electronic waste (old IT devices like laptops and other equipment). Over the last year, we reduced our office paper consumption by 23%, a total savings amount equal to covering half of New York’s Central Park. This is not only good for the planet, but it’s also important to our clients and our business. More and more of our clients are working to improve their environmental performance, making our own commitment relevant to meeting their needs. Here’s how you can get involved and make an impact: Join a local Green Team, which helps focus on waste reduction and improving recycling in our offices Use 'Ride Together', our new rideshare app Donate your device Top News

record.pwc_title: 5 things to keep in mind heading into filing season
record.pwc_description: What's new in A&C; process changes for e-filed state returns; obtain the required documentation when contracting with Individual clients; follow the Global Tax Code of Conduct; and protect confidential info.
record.pwc_body: 5 things to keep in mind heading into filing season 5 things to keep in mind heading into filing season One Firm Risk Organization Feb. 21, 2019 1. What we stand for: Take 5 minutes and read the Global Tax Code of Conduct. The Global Tax Code of Conduct covers the conduct of the member firms, who they should act for, and how they should act. 2. Do you have contract changes to standard terms and conditions? Here’s what you need to do. The approval of OFRO Tax is required as part of the A&C Engagement Acceptance Assessment sign-off process when there are changes to standard terms and conditions in a contract. To obtain OFRO Tax approval, mark “Yes” to question 2.4 of the Tax Engagement Acceptance Assessment and answer the questions that follow appropriately, providing commentary and documentation as necessary. Read more > 3. Do you e-file any state returns? Important changes to the process you need to know about. A new state e-file requirement related to application software updates will impact our internal PwC e-file process. If you calculate a return on one release, you have 10 business days after the next release to transmit the return to the IRS. Once those 10 business days have passed, the return has "expired," and will not be transmitted. Read more > 4. Individual Clients - What you need to know about contracting and obtaining consents and FROR confirmations. It is important that engagement teams working with our individual clients understand and follow the prescribed protocols for the following contract language and policies -- Financial Reporting Oversight Roles (FROR), Consent to Disclosure of Tax Return Information and Privacy Policy Notices. All Tax professionals (Associates through Partners), who provide services to individual clients - including PCS, PFS, Law Firm services, IAS, Investment Management and Real Estate practices - are required to take this course in Vantage Financial Reporting Oversight Roles. Read more > 5. Do you “need to know”? Protect client and firm confidential information. Access to client and firm confidential information should be limited to only those individuals that have a “need to know.” Disclosing or discussing confidential client information or private firm matters outside of the proper channels can put both you and the firm at risk. Read on for more on what you can do to protect client and firm confidential information. Top News

record.pwc_title: Top findings from the 2018 Annual Corporate Directors Survey
record.pwc_body: Top findings from the 2018 Annual Corporate Directors Survey Top findings from the 2018 Annual Corporate Directors Survey Governance Insights Center Feb. 25, 2019 A board of directors can heavily influence a management team on strategic decisions, leadership approaches and how to solve tough problems. But it’s not always easy to build a relationship with the board. The perfect opportunity to start a conversation: Our 2018 Annual Corporate Directors Survey provides insights from 700+ public company directors, with perspectives on topics from cultural oversight to cybersecurity to boardroom diversity. The survey is published by the Governance Insights Center -- a team dedicated to helping boards of directors meet the challenges of their critical roles and duties. Led by Paula Loop, the team meets with boards of directors, institutional executives and the C-suite to share leading practices in corporate governance; publishes practical thought leadership on boardroom hot topics; and hosts events on current governance issues. Three of our top findings provide a unique One Firm glimpse into the issues many clients are facing today: Social issues and strategy make a stronger connection Social issues are slowly making their way into the boardroom. In fact, directors are becoming more open to considering social issues when discussing company strategy. Issues such as healthcare availability and cost, resource scarcity and human rights are much higher on directors’ radars this year. The cybersecurity disconnect: Awareness is hot, crisis management is not Cybersecurity is a constantly moving target. Still, directors say they’re on the ball. They’re more comfortable with what their companies are doing around the topic, and they’re taking steps to prepare for a cyber incident. But a cyberattack can happen to any company at any time. Are boards really sure their company won’t be caught flat-footed if there’s a breach? Evaluating corporate culture: Going with your gut may not be enough A company’s culture isn’t always easy to define, but it drives what people do and don’t do. Boards need to help promote a strong culture – one that promotes the right behaviors throughout the company. So what do directors think is actually useful in their oversight role? Hearing from employees. Topping the list of the most useful metrics for evaluating the culture are employee engagement survey results, exit interview debriefs and feedback results for executives. Here are two steps you can take today to start building a stronger relationship with your client’s board: Contact Paula Loop and request a governance SME to come meet with your client’s board or management team about findings from the survey Use our Conversation starter letter to reach out to directors at your clients For more information: Visit our ACDS webpage Find our Conversation Starter letter on our US Governance Insights Center site Learn more about the Governance Insights Center Contact Paula Loop Top News

record.pwc_title: Consider obtaining an approved Framework AFS for recurring non-audit services at the beginning of the year
record.pwc_description: Guidance on the procedures to follow for restricted clients and/or their affiliates.
record.pwc_body: Consider obtaining an approved Framework AFS for recurring non-audit s Consider obtaining an approved Framework AFS for recurring non-audit services at the beginning of the year One Firm Risk Organization Sept. 6, 2018 Tax engagement teams should consider the use of a Framework AFS (Authorisation For Services) that is approved at the beginning of the year after audit committee approval has been received for recurring or known tax services to be provided to the client throughout the year. This can be an effective means of managing the Responsible Partner’s (as identified in CES) pre-approval obligations and can be extremely helpful in achieving compliance with firm policy. As background, many audit clients have a Pre-approval Framework Agreement in place, which is an approach used to obtain and document audit committee pre-approval for recurring or known (at the time of preparing the Framework) tax services to be provided to the client during the audit engagement period. For example, tax compliance and tax compliance related services provided annually and other types of detailed, pre-defined tax consulting services, may be included in a client’s Pre-Approval Framework Agreement to obtain Audit Committee pre-approval well in advance of actually engaging to provide the services. In these cases, the Framework AFS can be obtained after Audit Committee pre-approval is granted and should mirror the client’s Pre-approval Framework Agreement’s detailed scope of services for those pre-approved non-audit services. An approved Framework AFS will provide the necessary approvals to “clear the way” for engagement teams to be engaged to provide previously pre-approved tax services as requested by the client. However, care should be used to ensure that the non-audit services that are being provided clearly fall under the Framework AFS. In many cases, the Responsible Partner may still request that a separate AFS also be submitted as each project kicks off for notification/tracking purposes. If a separate AFS is requested, a best practice that should be considered is to also reference the Framework AFS at that time. Tax engagement teams should discuss with the respective Responsible Partner the procedures to be followed to obtain pre-approval for any non-audit services to be provided to their restricted clients and/or their affiliates, including whether a Pre-approval Framework Agreement has been agreed to with the client and the relevant PCAOB Rule 3524 communications have been made. If a Pre-approval Framework Agreement is not being used for your restricted client and/or their affiliate, consider having a discussion with the Responsible Partner regarding the use of a Pre-approval Framework Agreement approach. For additional information, see the Pre-approval Framework Agreements and Independence section on the Tax Independence microsite. Questions? Contact timothy.s.kirk@pwc.com, mike.mcdermott@pwc.com or amy.kavral@pwc.com. Top News

record.pwc_body: Check out built-in data manipulation in Mapper Check out built-in data manipulation in Mapper Tax May 20, 2019 Are you spending time manipulating client-provided excel files just so you can import the data into Mapper? record.pwc_title: How hackable are you? Security Awareness Month starts now
record.pwc_body: How hackable are you? Security Awareness Month starts now How hackable are you? Security Awareness Month starts now Network Information Security Oct. 1, 2018 Time to boost your security IQ We’re all very busy and eager to deliver quick results to our stakeholders and clients. But a moment of inattention or simply acting too quickly can potentially result in an information security incident ━ which could impact the firm, our clients and you. Good thing it’s Security Awareness Month! These next four weeks, through PwC Inside tips and digital upskilling activities, we’ll give you refreshers on how to be smart and secure in your everyday work. Remember, you are the first line of defense. First up: How hackers hack us Cybercriminals are often good social engineers, which means they do pre-work before sending out a phishing email. They may overhear confidential conversations at a public place, or set up an unencrypted WiFi hotspot. They may even create a fake LinkedIn profile and try to connect with you. Watch this brief film ━ Wrong Connection: A Social Engineering Story ━ to see how Carl Denton, a fictional PwC staff member, makes some easily avoidable mistakes that have a big impact. Learn more See this quick reference card on how to avoid the social engineering traps shown in the video. Visit our Information Security Awareness site for more tips and videos. To report an incident involving loss, misuse or unauthorized access to information, or to report suspected or known violations of privacy laws or policies, call the Ethics HelpLine at 1-888-4-ETHICS (1-888-438-4427). To boost your digital security acumen, follow the Tech While You Trek podcast and play PowerUp! on Tuesdays and Fridays at 2 p.m. ET. Check out the Digital Hub, our new central resource for all things digital upskilling, for PowerUp! pre-reads and more. Top News

record.pwc_title: Talent knows talent: Use Workday to refer candidates to PwC
record.pwc_body: Talent knows talent: Use Workday to refer candidates to PwC Talent knows talent: Use Workday to refer candidates to PwC People Team Feb. 18, 2019 Do you know someone who would be a great fit at PwC? Some of our best candidates come from your referrals. In fact, we’ve found that candidate referrals are quick to onboard and make an impact on the business. Most importantly, they stay with the firm longer. Referring experienced candidates is easy and must be done in Workday. Simply type “Find Jobs” in the Workday search bar to get started and find the job that suits someone you know. In order to receive credit for making a referral, you must submit your referral to a specific job. This will also give you visibility into your referral’s status throughout the process (simply type ”My Referrals” in the Workday search bar to see their progress). As an added incentive, if you you refer a candidate who is ultimately hired, you may be entitled to a referral reward. Please also note these important reminders: Only experienced referrals should be submitted through Workday. Refer to the Employee Referral Program site for guidance regarding entry-level referrals. To receive a referral reward, you must submit experienced referrals to a posted open role through Workday before your referral applies for the role. Immediately after you submit the experienced referral, the referred candidate will receive an automated email directing them to apply through a specific link. Your referral must use this referral link to apply for the role. If your referred candidate does not use the referral link, they will not be tagged as a referral and recruiters will not be notified that the candidate is a referral. For appropriate credit and status updates, referred candidates cannot be accepted through Google email or any other means except the Workday referral link. Your referred candidate’s status in Workday will not be visible to you until they have applied to the specific job via the referral link. For more information, take a moment to review the Employee Referral Program quick reference card (QRC) and policy. Make sure you follow the guidance above so you don’t miss out on a referral bonus! If you have questions about submitting referrals, please contact the Employee Referral Team. Top News

record.pwc_title: The sights and sounds of recognition -- give virtual high-fives through Real-time recognition
record.pwc_body: The sights and sounds of recognition -- give virtual high-fives throug The sights and sounds of recognition -- give virtual high-fives through Real-time recognition People Team Jan. 17, 2019 Real-time recognition is about honoring others for living our values, celebrating successes and boosting emotional well-being. Throughout FY19, we’re sharing Real-time recognition tips. In this article, we focus on the value of social recognition. Our world is increasingly more social because of technology and our connections to others have become essential to our growth and development. The Recognition activity feed in the Real-time recognition tool is one way we can show appreciation and motivate our colleagues by giving virtual high fives. Social recognition amplifies appreciation and strengthens relationships by creating a continuous loop of positive feedback. It enables everyone to see what people value, congratulate colleagues and be inspired to emulate the behavior. On the Recognition activity feed you can view awards received by your colleagues and add your own message of congratulations. Simply type a brief, thoughtful message and click Congratulate. Your message will appear in the feed and the recipient will receive an email summarizing the messages they’ve received. Tip! Awards with videos and photos get more congratulatory messages than those with only text, so when you’re recognizing someone, make it more meaningful and memorable by adding a photo or video. The maximum file size accepted is 40 MB. You may include a message along with your media. Refer to the User Guide for details on how to adjust privacy settings on the activity feed. Please don’t share client names, confidential information or any comments outside of our Code of Conduct in your recognition message. More info: Based on your feedback, we’ve added the option to recognize staff in the US with a $25 award. If you recognize staff in other territories, they will receive the same award level at a value in their home-country denomination. Use your Real-time recognition balance by Jan. 16, 2019 or you will lose it. Budgets are loaded twice per year to promote more frequent recognition -- half of your annual budget was loaded in the system in Sept. and the second half will be loaded on Jan. 17, 2019. (Note: You will see your spending balance during the recognition process on your PC.) Relationship Leaders can see if their assignees have been recognized by clicking the “My team” link on the Recognition home page. You can adjust the privacy settings on the Recognition activity feed. Keep an eye out for future installments of our tips series. Have you shown appreciation today? Visit Real-time recognition. Top News

record.pwc_title: Our top 5 takeaways from the Firmwide Town Hall
record.pwc_body: Our top 5 takeaways from the Firmwide Town Hall Our top 5 takeaways from the Firmwide Town Hall HQ News May 24, 2018 Wondering who won The habit challenge? Want to know how our Your Tomorrow efforts are going? Read our top five takeaways -- and Tim's three asks of all of us -- then get the full story by watching the replay of yesterday’s Town Hall: Your Tomorrow is happening today. Our world is evolving and PwC is evolving with it. Tim Ryan provided an update on all that’s happened since our last Town Hall back in October when we launched our Your Tomorrow strategy. Your Tomorrow is how we bring the best of the firm to our clients with more value and a more digital experience, and how we are building the skills we need to lead and thrive. Since last fall, we’ve downloaded nearly 150,000 apps from PwC’s App store (including the wildly popular Calm app), more than 45,000 of us have taken part in a habit plan as part of our Be well, work well efforts, and 3,500 of us have self-nominated to become Digital Accelerators. And our July 4 firmwide week-long shutdown was a result of the tremendous progress we made through the Your Tomorrow, Our Time Off challenge in the US, while the challenge continues in Mexico. But there’s still lots more to come. Your Tomorrow is all about our investment in you -- and in transforming PwC for a digital future. Chief Digital Officer Joe Atkinson shared a preview of what we can expect in the future as part of our Your Tomorrow strategy, including our pledge to get Digitally Fit by the end of FY19 through podcasts, quizzes, market-based events and more. He also talked about our efforts to build a world-class data platform, one that provides access to the right data anywhere, anytime, securely and on any device. He even shared a “day in the life” view of what our firm will look like 12-18 months from now, based on technology and initiatives that are already here or currently in development! We’re skill building -- in our firm and in our communities. In addition to the plan Joe laid out for digitally upskilling our own people, he shared a video that demonstrated the power of our Access Your Potential® commitment to build technology skills of students from overlooked and underserved communities through our partnership with Code.org. Access Your Potential® includes three pillars: Along with building tech skills, we continue to focus on financial literacy (building on the foundation set through our Earn Your Future® efforts) and mentoring. You can find similar Access Your Potential® volunteer opportunities on Impact Space. And the winner is … We had some amazing entries for The habit challenge, but at the end of the day, The Real Auditors of Estero took home the big prize … and the oversized plane ticket! Southeast Market People Leader Melisa Cook made the presentation to team leader Arionna Gunderman. Arionna shared that by making a couple of small habit changes, the team was able to see big results … and win the grand prize of a three-day, two-night stay at a luxury resort and round-trip airfare for each team member and a companion, and a $250 resort voucher! Read more about The Real Auditors of Estero, and all of our Top 50 The habit challenge finalists, here. Upward and peer feedback is coming back! Melisa joined Tim for a Q&A segment featuring some of your most frequently asked questions. Joe provided detailed information around what’s next for our Digital Accelerators program, and Tim shared updates on our response to the #MeToo movement, telling our digital story and that our popular upward and peer feedback program would be coming back and would be better than ever, since it will now be available year-round. Upward and peer feedback functionality will be available through Workday, our new global, mobile, and cloud-based human capital system. With the Workday launch, Tim also shared that our PwC Professional framework is now simpler, clearer and aligned to our new global staff levels. Watch for more information on Workday coming later this summer! Tim’s 3 “asks” Tim also shared his three “asks” of all of us: Become Digitally Fit by continuing to leverage the Digital Fitness app and by taking advantage of Digital Upskilling opportunities once they roll out. Also, if you’re interested in becoming a Digital Accelerator, watch for more information on how to apply the next time the nomination window opens! Tell our story. We’re creating materials that will help you communicate to our clients around our digital journey. Once available, make sure you understand our story yourself, and are able to share it with your clients, stakeholders, professional and social networks. There’s nothing more powerful than hearing firsthand the impact that the changes we’re making is having on our firm. Work together to drive our strategy forward. We’ve got an ambitious agenda in front of us, and it will only work if we’re all pulling in the same direction. Talk with your team about how you can get Digitally Fit together. Leverage the Chatter feature in Salesforce. Respectfully challenge each other to bring out the best in one another. Create a teamBe well, work well plan. Support each other and learn from each other, because we’ll go farther together. You can watch the full replay here. Top News

record.pwc_body: Have you heard? We've updated the primary credential policy! Have you heard? We've updated the primary credential policy! Assurance March 4, 2019 Effective March 1, 2019, Assurance will no longer require associates to pass a primary credential exam for promotion to senior associate. Hear directly from our Assurance People Leader, Laura Martinez, to find out what is changing and what it means for you. While Assurance no longer requires primary credential exams for promotion to senior associate, achieving a credential as early in your career as possible continues to be very important. To further support you in achieving your credential early, here are a few additional enhancements to the policy that you should be aware of: We are increasing the Assurance primary credential exam bonuses to reward those associates who pass exams early. The increased bonus awards are retroactive for all current associates and those who were promoted January 1, 2019 to senior associate who have already received a primary credential bonus. The incremental bonus amounts will be paid on April 30, 2019. Associates will have 40 hours per year of protected time to book in TalentLink to study for your primary credential exam. Your deployment team will help you schedule this time based on client demands. For those who have an expired Becker license and are eligible to renew the program at the PwC discounted price under the Becker Promise they will only be responsible to pay 50% of the cost - the firm will cover the other 50% one additional time. record.pwc_body: How to avoid career FOMO: Apply to be a Digital Accelerator today How to avoid career FOMO: Apply to be a Digital Accelerator today Tax May 23, 2019 Want to know the easiest thing you can do to avoid career FOMO in the next week? Apply to be a Digital Accelerator in Tax. As part of Your Tomorrow - Project 5 Million, we all have a role to play in elevating our digital capabilities in order to address our clients’ most pressing challenges. Those who are accepted to the Digital Accelerator program will not only build critical skills -- they will gain new partner relationships and connection points, as well as increased influence within the Tax practice and the firm. As a DA, you would be at the forefront of transforming the Tax practice — as an engine of change and a strategic leader of the future. The Digital Accelerator program is one of the best ways to ensure that you get the client-facing digital experience that you need to differentiate your career in a changing world. No matter your staff level or how you identify yourself as a professional, anyone can benefit from this immersive, hands-on opportunity. No prior technology skills or experience are needed to apply -- just a keen interest in digital technologies and a desire to work on something cutting edge, while adding value to our clients and the firm. And it couldn’t be easier to apply. Just click here to submit a quick self-nomination. But don’t procrastinate -- the self-nomination deadline is Tuesday, May 28. Still have questions? record.pwc_title: Say ‘bye, bye, bye’ to Lotus Notes
record.pwc_body: Say ‘bye, bye, bye’ to Lotus Notes Say ‘bye, bye, bye’ to Lotus Notes Chief Data Office Feb. 4, 2019 We’re sunsetting Lotus Notes in phases -- last month we deleted all of our old email archives, releasing more than 100 terabytes of redundant, obsolete and trivial data. The next step on this simplification journey is retiring unneeded Lotus Notes applications and databases. We’ll start that process Feb. 28. Read on to find out how to prepare. What to expect First, rest assured that any business-critical tasks currently operating in Lotus Notes applications and databases (things like Advisory map, financial reporting applications and work request databases) will not be retired until they have been successfully replatformed — and we’ll give you plenty of notice before that happens. However, in addition to those “high-usage” applications and databases, we’ve also identified thousands of low-user-count applications and databases that may have little business value. On Feb. 28, we will begin turning off access for those low-user-count Lotus Notes applications and databases. After a sufficient period of inactivity, retired applications and databases will be archived and eventually deleted (except those subject to an OGC Legal Hold). But wait! What about the [fill-in-the-blank] application? I need that! Your IT and business leaders have confidence we’ve identified and made plans to replatform the Lotus Notes applications and databases that have business value. However, you can double-check to see whether an application or database you use regularly is scheduled to be turned off: Navigate to this database review tool. If you discover an application or database that needs to be kept beyond Feb. 28, 2019 — including anything subject to an OGC Legal Hold — simply follow the system prompts to request an exception. Your IT leaders will review your request to help you retain the information you need or to replatform to a new system. After Feb. 28, if you realize an application or database that’s been turned off needs to be recovered, you can have it temporarily reactivated by submitting a ticket through PwC’s Service Hub. We’ll provide access for a period of time and help you find a more tech-enabled way to manage related tasks going forward. Still have questions? Visit our Data Remediation page for FAQs, tools and resources to help you find, move and appropriately store any information in Lotus Notes that continues to hold business value. Get help! Visit PwC’s Service Hub for a full list of support options, including one-on-one reservations for IT support. Next steps toward moving away from old systems Replatforming and retiring Lotus Notes applications and databases is an important step — but we also have some other outdated systems that need retiring. Here’s what you can expect as we keep moving forward: This spring, we’ll prepare to turn off (and eventually delete) legacy shared drives. By the end of FY19, we’ll put in place a new 18-month retention period on our current Lotus Notes mailboxes. (In plain English, this means we’ll start automatically deleting Lotus Notes emails when they hit the 18-month-old milestone.) We’ll also introduce similar retention policies for our Google Mail and calendar events -- and lengthier data retention policies for Google Drive, Google Keep, Sites and G+ content. (We’ll give you plenty of notice, but you can start to prepare now by refreshing yourself on our systems for storing and managing records and for collaboration.) Later this year, we’ll be ready to delete everyone’s last Lotus Notes email archive and stop issuing Lotus Notes profiles to new joiners. Remind me: Why are we doing this? The way we approach data as a firm is changing. As part of a multi-year data journey, we’ve implemented robust, modern systems for storing and managing records and for collaboration. At the same time, we’re retiring outdated data storage systems; deleting redundant, obsolete and trivial data; and implementing best-in-class guidance for actively managing the data lifecycle. record.pwc_title: We are IFS: Laurel Ostiguy follows her dreams of becoming an author
record.pwc_body: We are IFS: Laurel Ostiguy follows her dreams of becoming an author We are IFS: Laurel Ostiguy follows her dreams of becoming an author IFS Aug. 6, 2018 “We are IFS” focuses on fun and inspiring stories from our IFS colleagues. Laurel Ostiguy, a Boston-based manager in National Office Services, couldn't ignore her dream of becoming an author any longer. "For a long time I tried to quell the overwhelming urge to write a book, until it basically wrote itself," she said. Laurel always knew she had a story inside her, even as a child. When she found herself with a two-hour, round-trip commute a few years ago, the time was right. "I had plenty of time to think the story through and literally record my thoughts, using my iPhone," she said. "And one day, I just began writing it!" She had help along the way, including advice to self-publish. "A friend introduced me to an author who provided tips on how to network and find an editor, cover designer and photographer," she shared. The more people she spoke with, the more it all seemed to fall into place. "At one point I said to myself, 'I really am doing this,' and just kept going." Her first novel, Last Goodbye, was published in 2015 and took four years to write. It was met with positive acclaim, but not before she hired beta readers to review it. "Beta readers are trained to actually rip a transcript apart to give you the absolute painful truth about your story and your writing," she said. "In my case, the feedback they provided was constructive -- and invaluable. When you get a compliment from them, it's a very big deal." Longing to Be followed in 2016, Lying in Wait comes out later this year and Lessons in Love will be released in 2020. All of her books share an ongoing storyline. "The premise of the series follows the journey of several characters from their freshman year of college through graduation, with lots of twists and turns," she said. How does she find the time to write? "I take advantage of PwC’s flexible work environment and now work from home,” she said. “Without that lengthy commute, I have more flexibility to write in the evenings and on weekends. My husband and two young children are very supportive. I love my job at PwC and I love that I can pursue my dream as an author!" A role model for aspiring authors Book signing gigs are another perk. "I love to encourage young aspiring writers,” she said. “Making connections is what it’s all about.” Laurel also donates her books to libraries and auctions. "Self-publishing is very popular these days, and I really recommend it," she said. This means she covers the cost of proofing, printing and design. The books are printed but also available online for Kindle, Nook, iPhone, Amazon and more. "And it's always a treat to read positive reviews, whether they appear in a local newspaper, on Amazon or even on Instagram," she said. Laurel is thrilled to see her passion come to life. "I used to walk in bookstores and say 'why not me?'" Indeed, why not? Find out more about Laurel and her books at www.laurelostiguy.com. Who’s inspiring you in a unique way? Help us tell their #TeamPwC story! Reach out with your “We are IFS” story ideas. Top News

record.pwc_title: Integrated Solution FOR THE WIN at NOVA Chemicals
record.pwc_body: Integrated Solution FOR THE WIN at NOVA Chemicals Integrated Solution FOR THE WIN at NOVA Chemicals Advisory - test March 14, 2019 What were NOVA’s key objectives? NOVA’s Gen Z program was focused on an enterprise-wide, multi-year digital transformation. The key objective was to implement SAP cloud solutions, in particular SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP), to restructure the antiquated supply chain and financial planning business processes, modernize the aging IT platform to decrease operational costs and streamline the supply chain to create a completely integrated ecosystem that's transparent to all functions involved. What was our proposed solution for NOVA? Using the Integrated Business Planning (IBP) Integrated Solution, and a BXT delivery method, we proposed a unifying supply chain platform leveraging the “Power or the Firm” with best practices from the IBP Integrated Solution playbook, and input from our strategy, management and technology consulting areas across the US and Canada. To solidify the relationship with NOVA and secure the win, we demonstrated chemical industry thought leadership combined with clear articulation of how PwC’s SAP IBP, IDeA, and SCOOP digital tools would deliver value. During orals, we made NOVA feel comfortable by taking extra time during breaks to walk through PwC’s pre-built digital enablers, helping NOVA understand the experience of working with us. What is Integrated Business Planning Integrated Solution? Integrated business planning (IBP) is a strategy for connecting the planning functions (sales and operations planning) in an organization to align operations and strategy with the organization's financial performance (financial planning and analysis). IBP includes functions such as demand planning, sales revenue planning, inventory optimization, product cost planning, detailed scheduling and operational expense planning. The IBP Integrated Solution team has built a delivery playbook with guidance, tools and templates to leverage, and project plans to help deliver in a repeatable and efficient way. What value will NOVA see using our solution? The Integrated Business Planning Integrated Solution will not only drive a one-time working capital reduction of $23 million for NOVA but also reduce over $1 million in annually recurring expenses. Equally important, this solution will retire the aging supply chain IT tools and create improved cross-functional visibility of key supply chain information. To date, we have already identified $12 million in finished goods inventory reduction opportunities and leveraged PwC’s SCOOP Intelligent Forecasting Platform (IFP) to improve forecast accuracy by greater than 15 percent. Meet the team! Want to learn more about Integrated Solutions? Check out Consulting Source and the Integrated Solutions Learning Hub. Top News

record.pwc_title: Do you work with our individual clients? Remember these FROR rules and other contracting protocols
record.pwc_description: Follow the prescribed protocols for contract language and policies - Financial Reporting Oversight Roles (FROR), Consent to Disclosure of Tax Return Information and Privacy Policy Notices.
record.pwc_body: Do you work with our individual clients? Remember these FROR rules and Do you work with our individual clients? Remember these FROR rules and other contracting protocols One Firm Risk Organization Jan. 23, 2019 As part of our continuous efforts to support the Tax line of service through regular communications, we are calling attention to the following contract language and policies -- Financial Reporting Oversight Roles (FROR), Consent to Disclosure of Tax Return Information and Privacy Policy Notices. Given the regulatory environment in which we work and the independence issues that could result from a failure to comply with the Tax LOS policy in these areas, it is important that engagement teams working with our individual clients understand and follow the prescribed protocols. The Tax Engagement Compliance Review Program and Office Review Program results have highlighted the need for increased diligence from our teams to include all required language in engagement contracts, obtain the required confirmations from our clients and execute the delivery of services in accordance with our risk management and independence guidance. When contracting with individual clients (including spouses and financially dependent relatives), engagement teams should remember the following: Engagement teams are responsible for ensuring that they do not provide tax services to individuals who are within the scope of PCAOB Rule 3523. Providing services to an individual (including spouses and financially dependent relatives) in a FROR position is an impermissible service and could result in a reportable independence violation. The Engagement Letters Index contains links to the templates for individual tax compliance services which includes FROR and Consent to Disclosure of Tax Return Information language requesting confirmation and consent from the individual client before engaging to provide services. The engagement letter templates used for individual services provides a Privacy Notice that is included with the annual engagement letter as an attachment. Our Privacy Policy provides a better understanding to our clients of our commitment to keeping client personal information confidential. RECOMMENDATION – If you are providing individual tax services and you are not in the PFS practice, be sure to make use of the PCS Q&RM Busy Season Toolkit and engagement letter templates or preferably, enlist a PFS specialist to assist you through the engagement set-up process. Financial Reporting Oversight Roles (FROR) FROR rules are covered under PCAOB Rule 3523. In summary, a registered public accounting firm is not independent of its audit client if the firm, or any affiliate of the firm, during the audit engagement period provides any tax service to a person in a financial reporting oversight role at the audit client. The Tax LOS has issued policies and tools in this area to assist engagement teams in obtaining the necessary sign-offs and acknowledgements from their individual clients. Our Review Program results highlight that engagement teams are not consistently obtaining client verification as to whether or not the client(s) is/are in a financial reporting oversight role (FROR) in the following key areas: Engagements for an individual who receives services under the terms of a Corporate Compliance or Consulting contract. Such engagements require FROR confirmations from all individuals for which tax returns are prepared. Engagements for an individual who receives services under the terms of a Family Office Services or Corporate Executive Program contract. Such engagements require FROR confirmations from all individuals for which tax returns are prepared. Engagements performed under a multi-year contract. Such engagements require FROR confirmation annually. Engagements to perform FBAR services for an individual who is an authorized signatory. Such engagements require FROR confirmation (see Foreign Bank Account Reporting (FBAR)). Consent to Disclosure of Tax Return Information Section 7216 consent must be obtained for all tax compliance and consulting engagements for individuals due to the nature of our business operations (e.g., use of GDM resources, third party contractors, back office support, etc.) and if the client requests that we disclose the client's tax return information to their representatives or professional advisors (e.g., the client's legal counsel, secretary, head (or CFO) of family office, etc.). This consent must be obtained prior to disclosing information to third parties. The consent must be signed by the client. Please note that the Consent to Disclosure of Tax Return Information must be obtained annually, including in the case of a multi-year contract. Do not reduce the font size of the Consent to Disclosure of Tax Return Information document below 12 points. This font size is required in order to comply with regulations and procedures under Section 7216. Privacy Policy Notice Tax LOS policy requires that privacy notices be sent to clients when providing individual tax (compliance and consulting) services. The GLBA Privacy Notice must be provided when the client relationship commences. For existing clients, an annual notice must be provided every calendar year. Engagement teams should be sure to use the most current engagement letter templates from the Engagement Letters Index. For your reference, below are links to frequently used documents and other helpful sites. Engagement Letters: Tax Compliance: Individuals (also contains the "Consents to Disclosure of Tax Return Information" form) Individual Tax Organizer Documents 2018 PCS Q&RM Busy Season Toolkit For further information contact any member of the OFRO Tax team or your PCS/PFS Q&RM representative with questions. record.pwc_title: Prepare your clients for the Workforce of the Future
record.pwc_body: Prepare your clients for the Workforce of the Future Prepare your clients for the Workforce of the Future Platforms Jan. 18, 2019 The "future of work" is one of the hottest topics companies and employees are discussing across the board, and we have a webcast series to help you better understand and deliver effective strategies to our clients. As one of the firm's strategic platforms, Workforce of the Future helps clients respond to the major demographic, social and technological shifts that are disrupting workforces. Our firmwide capabilities can position them for success for today and tomorrow. Platform: Workforce of the Future - Digital Workforce Transformation Friday, January 25, 2019 2-3 p.m. ET Click here to register Clients business strategy and investments require a workforce steeped in existing and emerging technologies linked to new ways of working and learning. In this new world, coupling tools with a continuous learning culture and a business outcome mindset is key to digital upskilling.
